title.value: Brain decoding of the Human Connectome Project tasks in a dense individual fMRI dataset
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Brain decoding of the Human Connectome Project tasks in a dense individual fMRI dataset

extractions.description: This paper explores the feasibility of training accurate brain decoding models at the individual level using dense individual fMRI data from the Human Connectome Project. It evaluates nine different models, including SVM, MLP, and GCN, for classifying brain activity into various cognitive task conditions.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments with multiple classifiers on a dense individual fMRI dataset to train and assess brain decoding models, which indicates empirical research.
type.quote: In this paper, we tested whether accurate brain decoding models can be trained entirely at the individual level.

name.justification: The research focuses on decoding cognitive states from patterns of brain activity, specifically in the context of brain decoding.
name.quote: Brain decoding aims to infer cognitive states from patterns of brain activity.

name.justification: The research extensively utilizes functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging for brain activity data.
name.quote: Brain decoding aims to infer cognitive states from snapshots of brain activity captured with techniques like functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI, Fig. 1).

name.justification: The research uses machine learning models to classify brain activity patterns.
name.quote: Multiple machine-learning models to analyze individual-level brain data.

name.justification: The paper discusses experimenting with GCN models for brain activity classification.
name.quote: We also evaluated a GCN model whose implementation was adapted from our team’s previous work.

name.justification: The paper benchmarks Support Vector Machines for brain activity classification.
name.quote: We evaluated nine decoding methods, from Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to Graph Convolutional Neural Networks (GCN).

name.justification: The paper specifically investigates the use of GCN for brain decoding tasks.
name.quote: We also evaluated a GCN model whose implementation was adapted from our team’s previous work.

is_contributed.justification: The GCN model is adapted from previous work, indicating it is not a newly contributed model.
is_contributed.quote: We also evaluated a GCN model whose implementation was adapted from our team’s previous work.

is_executed.justification: The GCN model was executed and its performance evaluated as part of the study.
is_executed.quote: The top-performing methods were GCN and MLP, reaching up to 67 % prediction accuracy across the 21 task conditions.

is_compared.justification: The performance of the GCN model is compared with other models like MLP and SVM in terms of prediction accuracy.
is_compared.quote: We evaluated nine decoding methods, from Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to Graph Convolutional Neural Networks (GCN).

referenced_paper_title.value: Functional annotation of human cognitive states using deep graph convolution
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references Zhang et al., 2021 for the GCN model implementation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The classifiers underwent training and testing using a leave-one-run-out cross-validation method implemented in Scikit-learn. To optimize the hyperparameters, a nested cross-validation approach was adopted.

name.justification: The study evaluates MLP as one of the key models for brain decoding.
name.quote: The top-performing methods were GCN and MLP, reaching up to 67 % prediction accuracy across the 21 task conditions.

is_contributed.justification: MLP is a common model architecture used in various studies, not contributed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: The top-performing methods were GCN and MLP, reaching up to 67 % prediction accuracy across the 21 task conditions.

is_executed.justification: MLP was executed in this study to classify fMRI data.
is_executed.quote: The classifiers underwent training and testing using a leave-one-run-out cross-validation method implemented in Scikit-learn.

is_compared.justification: MLP's performance is compared with GCN and SVM, as the study aims to identify the best-performing model.
is_compared.quote: The top-performing methods were GCN and MLP, reaching up to 67 % prediction accuracy across the 21 task conditions.

referenced_paper_title.value: Auto-ASD-network: a technique based on deep learning and support vector machines for diagnosing autism spectrum disorder using fMRI data
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references this study by Eslami and Saeed, 2019 for methodologies incorporating MLP.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Models included eight conventional machine learning algorithms: Support Vector Classification (SVM), Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) ...

name.justification: The dataset used for the study is the HCP's test-retest dataset adapted for the current project.
name.quote: We used the HCP test-retest (hcptrt) dataset from the CNeuroMod databank.

referenced_paper_title.value: The WU-Minn Human Connectome Project: an overview.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The original dataset is well-known and cited, hence the use of 'used' label.
referenced_paper_title.quote: CNeuroMod’s hcptrt, a dense individual fMRI dataset. We used the HCP test-retest (hcptrt) dataset from the CNeuroMod databank.

name.justification: The Natural Scenes Dataset (NSD) is referenced as an example of emerging deep phenotyping datasets.
name.quote: Deep phenotyping datasets are now becoming available for specific domains such as vision (e.g., the Natural Scenes Dataset (NSD)) (Allen et al., 2022)...

referenced_paper_title.value: A massive 7T fMRI dataset to bridge cognitive neuroscience and artificial intelligence
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper by Allen et al., 2022 on the NSD dataset is referenced to demonstrate the existence of deep phenotyping datasets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Deep phenotyping datasets are now becoming available for specific domains such as vision (e.g., the Natural Scenes Dataset (NSD)) (Allen et al., 2022)...

name.justification: The MSC dataset is used for comparison with the individual brain decoding analysis, highlighting inter-subject variability.
name.quote: This dataset and our benchmark can be useful to assess brain decoding models in order to reveal individual-specific aspects of brain organization...

referenced_paper_title.value: Precision functional mapping of individual human brains
referenced_paper_title.justification: The study by Gordon et al., 2017 discusses intra- and inter-subject variability with reference to the MSC dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This study reported intra-subject decoding that was significantly better than inter-subject decoding, highlighting the challenges of high inter-subject variability.

name.justification: The Scikit-learn library was used for implementing several machine learning models in the study.
name.quote: Multiple machine-learning models to analyze individual-level brain data.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The usage of Scikit-learn in implementing machine learning models is common and referenced in Pedregosa et al., 2011.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Multiple machine-learning models to analyze individual-level brain data.

name.justification: The PyTorch library was used to implement the GCN model in this study.
name.quote: We used backpropagation to train the model using PyTorch 1.8.1.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep learning models of cognitive processes constrained by human brain connectomes
referenced_paper_title.justification: PyTorch is referenced in the paper and linked to deep learning implementations.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We used backpropagation to train the model using PyTorch 1.8.1...The network was trained for 10 epochs with batch sizes of 10.
